content:
Fusion Festival是一个有着浓烈反主流文化的音乐节。它在德国东北部它梅克伦堡-前波莫瑞州的前军用机场米利茨举办。音乐节名称通常用西里尔字母表示为Фузион，但发音类似于英语单词Fusion [ 'fjuʒən ]，所以也叫做Fusion Festival。

 

一年一度的音乐节由1997年成立的Kulturkosmos组织，为期四到六天。2016年，Fusion Festival于6月29日至7月3日举行，自2013年活动以来，每年的音乐节吸引了约70,000参与者，而同类的美国火人音乐节在2015年才举办。

 

音乐节上呈现了不同的音乐风格，但事先没有发布阵容。和开盲盒一样，但是各种现场音乐表演没有风格上的限制，音乐节的参加者可以携带自己的乐器。电影节还举办自己的电影节，并设有不同规模的艺术装置。与会者可能会带来自己的艺术作品并出现在展览中。值得一提的是，节日期间仅出售素食。

 

Fusion Festival旨在创造一个临时的没有拘束的区域和一个充满变革的氛围。由于Fusion Festival的前卫态度和艺术多样性，Fusion Festival被称为“欧洲火人音乐节”。

 

概念

Fusion Festival结合了各种各样风格的电子音乐，有时取决于会选择播放自己音乐的参与者们。 该音乐节被描述为一个人们能解放思想，摆脱日常生活、工作，学习和其他责任的空间。这是通过音乐寻找“人们被迫居住”的系统的替代结果。人们前往Fusion体验了一种不同的社交和生活方式，在这里彼此自由地体验，分享对音乐和艺术的热爱，将不同的场景和思想联系在一起。该音乐节部分是服装选购的活动。艺术部分包括表演艺术，静态艺术品，雕塑，艺术车和其他各种形式。

 

音乐节现场

Fusion Festival始于1997年，位于德国东北部的拉兹市附近，距柏林约160公里（100英里），距汉堡约230公里（140英里）。 该位置位于废弃的Erprobungsstelle Rechlin第三帝国时代中央军事实验机场的原始草皮地面上（东经53°20′48.11″ N 12°44′23.25″ E，占地234公顷（580英亩）中心场）距现代化的Rechlin-Lärz机场区以北约4.5公里（2.8英里）。该地址最初是由德意志帝国收购，在1916年成为航空科研和训练场，在1918年八月公开设备予Luftstreitkräfte使用。1935年德国空军成立后，它一直是第三帝国的Erprobungsstelle Rechlin中央军用飞机测试设施直到1945早年间。1945年5月2日被苏联红军占领，供VVS使用。那时有一些草覆盖的混凝土机库（实际的掩体）用于苏联战斗机（因此音乐节名称和各个阶段的西里尔字母音译，因为现场仍然有许多西里尔字母铭文）。该机场于1994年重新开放供民用，并于2010年出售给MüritzAirpark Group。
contentEn:
The Fusion Festival is a music and arts festival with a countercultural character. It takes place at a former military airport called Müritz Airpark in Lärz, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, in northeastern Germany. The festival name is often depicted in Cyrillic letters as Фузион, but pronounced like the English word fusion ['fjuʒən]. The annual festival was started by the Kulturkosmos organisation in 1997. It lasts four to six days, usually at the end of June. In 2016, the Fusion Festival event took place from June 29 - July 3, and which has attracted some 70,000 attendees for each year's festival, since the 2013 event, which the comparable American Burning Man event only matched in 2015.[1]

 

Different musical styles are represented at the festival, but the line up is not released beforehand. Mostly electronic music is present, but there is no stylistic restriction for the various live music acts, and the festival attendees may bring their own instruments. The festival also holds its own film festival and features different scales of art installations. Attendees may bring their own art and appear in artistic costumes. Only vegetarian food is sold at the festival grounds.

 

The festival gears to create a Temporary Autonomous Zone and a transformational environment. Due to its avantgardistic attitude and the variety of art, the Fusion Festival has been described as a "European Burning Man".[2]

 

Concept

The Fusion Festival combines all styles of the underground electronic music scene and various other styles, sometimes depending on the attendees who choose to play their own music.[2][3] It is described as a space people go to free their minds from their everyday lives, jobs, studies and other responsibilities. It is the result of the search for an alternative through music, to the system "people are forced to live in". People go to the Fusion to experience a different way of socializing and living, where experiencing one another freely, sharing love for music and art connects different scenes and minds. It is partially a clothing-optional event. Art installations include performance arts, static artworks, sculptures, art cars and various other forms.[4]

 

Festival site

Fusion Festival began in 1997 near the city of Lärz[5] in north-eastern Germany, about 160 km (100 mi) from Berlin and 230 km (140 mi) from Hamburg.[6]

 

The location is on the original grass-covered grounds of the disused Erprobungsstelle Rechlin Third Reich-era central military experimental airfield (at 53°20′48.11″N 12°44′23.25″E for the 234-hectare (580-acre) area central field) about 4.5 km (2.8 mi) due north of the modern Rechlin-Lärz Airfield facility. The site was first acquired by the German Empire in 1916 as an aviation research and training ground, opening the facility for use by the Luftstreitkräfte in August 1918. After the establishment of the Luftwaffe in 1935, the field served as the Erprobungsstelle Rechlin central military aircraft test facility of the Third Reich through early 1945, and it was captured by the Soviet Red Army on May 2, 1945, for use by the VVS. There are grass-covered concrete hangars (actual bunkers) from that time that were used for Soviet fighter aircraft (hence the Cyrillic transliteration of the festival name and various stages, as many Cyrillic inscriptions were still present on the site). The airfield was reopened for civilian use in 1994 and sold to the Müritz Airpark Group in 2010.[7]
